text: (upbeat music)
- Welcome, everyone. I'm Cheryl Cage.

I'm a senior security
partner strategist with AWS

and I am on the security
compliance partner team.

And today, I wanna introduce
you to two of our partners

that we're going to be talking
about SOC 2 compliance.
I wanna introduce DuploCloud and A-LIGN.

I'm happy to have you join
us today for a great talk,
and we're happy to have you show everyone,
the great things that you're doing

around security, automation,
and acceleration.
We did discuss scoping a little bit.

So, what are some tools that
can help that customer though?

Is it making sure that they
have reference architecture?
Is it data flow diagrams, asset inventory?
What kind of tools do they need

to help you figure out
what their scope is?
- Yeah, I think, if we go back
to the people process and technology,
that really is what it's anchored in

- Mm-hmm.
- and it's in and around
that service that they're certifying.
- So, there's a number of tools and things
that we can do,

and we should share with
our clients to help them.

So, one of our main,
essentially our main product,

when it comes to managing
and running these audits

is our proprietary in-house
tool that we call A-SCEND,

which is basically a
project management tool

where both the client
and we have access to it.

And that's where the
project lives, if you will.
So, all the requests,

all the things that we're gonna
need to complete the project

are gonna basically flow
through that portal.
So, that's the starting point.
And the client can come in there and say,

okay, hey, here's the
general list of requests.
Get a feel for what the asks are gonna be

and how much heavy lifting
is gonna be required.
And then, from there, obviously,
we have a number of policies, procedures,
template documents, that sort of thing
that we can share with the client,

especially if they're in the
more immature shall we say,
cycle of the audit

and they're just coming
to us for the first time.

There's a lot of, you
mentioned network diagrams,

security policies and procedures,
all those kinds of things.
We can guide the client

to help them get up to
speed on what they need to.
And then, from there,

the idea is that going
forward, things will mature.
Things will get built out over time.
So, it's just a starting point.
And then, we go from there.
- Connor does bring up a good point.
SOC 2 is very documentation-heavy,
so you need to have

all those policies and
procedures in place.
How does DuploCloud help with that?
- Yeah, I think, what we tend to do

is that we have more on
the implementation side.

- Mm-hmm.
- So, our general goal

is that if the customer
is using DuploCloud,
as far as the AWS controls are concerned,

by and large, they don't have
to worry about it, period.

Our goal is that when the
readiness assessment happens,
they come in,

they're there like 90%
of the time, for example.
But at the same time, it's not something

that they really need to
worry about underneath it.
And then, they're just using it.
Then, comes the policy aspect of it.

So, as far as the AWS
infrastructure policies
are concerned, (clears throat)
I think, we would give them controls
and then

we would help them with the
template policies and stuff,

but that's typically when
they actually talk to A-LIGN

and so forth is when they
nail down their policies.
But what we have done beforehand

is that we've already
set in the best practices

and gotten them 90% there
in terms of implementation,
as far as AWS is concerned.
- And we're talking,

I wanna get into the
automation aspect of SOC 2

and how does DuploCloud
help automate that process?
Someone comes to you and says,
I need to get SOC 2 type one tomorrow.
- Right.
- How do you make that happen?
- Yeah, so when somebody says like that,
the first question we ask them,
is that like, okay, what do you have?
How big is your infrastructure?
And when you set up that infrastructure,
did you have SOC 2 in mind?
Did you put in those controls?
So, now, let's say the answer is,
oh, I have a huge infrastructure,

hundreds of virtual machines
and workloads and containers.
I didn't think about SOC 2.
Then you're like, oh, oops, okay.
We need to figure out like how to do that.

But on the other hand, if
they basically say that, okay,
I have a rather small infrastructure
that what we could do is that, okay,
you go and install the software.

That automatically pushes
much of the SOC 2 controls.

And you could basically
split SOC 2 controls
into two pieces,

provisioning time controls and
post-provisioning controls.

Post-provisioning controls
are monitoring controls.
If security group goes off or the CPUs
and the memory and those kind of things,
those are easy to basically apply.

Regardless of whether you
have an infrastructure or not,
we basically go and enable it.

And then, it'll start monitoring
the system and let you.

But those constitute, I
would say from my experience,

about 30 to 40% of the
overall control set,
but 60% is actually provisioning time.
Like you say,

you want to prevent a
disease, not cure disease.
So, our focus is to see

how they can be SCO 2
compliance at the get-go.
So, timing is really important.

So, if they are talking
to us at the right time,

we can make sure that SOC
2 is something out of box
and they don't have to worry about,

and all the automation is
there, like we'll get them 95%.
But if they are talking to
at a much later time in the journey,
we probably can get them 40% there,
right away with a few button clicks.
And then, we have to work with them

and figure out how to do
things in a non-destructive.
- And so, DuploCloud,

it's DevSecOps platform.
- Right.
So, how much time and money
can the average company save
by not having to hire all those people

to do that work?
- Right, right.
What we have typically seen

is about four to five
weeks, their infrastructure.
If we talk to them at the right time,
the infrastructure would be compliant.

And I would say that a lot
of our customers who are,

let's say, less than
50 VMs or maybe 75 VMs,

they may not have an
in-house DevOps engineer.
The larger ones do have.
But it's an order of magnitude basically.
Like what I have seen in the industry

is that if you're talking
about 60 controls,
two, three days of control,

and they're taking a long
time, basically like months.
With DuploCloud, I think,

it's maybe about four to six
weeks is what I would say

to get to that stage
where they're 95% there.

And again, I'm talking about
the cloud infrastructure.

There's a lot that
happens outside of that.
The endpoint security and the processes.
That part takes some time,

but with DuploCloud, I
think, the AWS part is given.
It's there.
- And we're talking about automation too.

And in the past, auditing has
been a very manual process

and we're starting to see
more automation built in
in the auditing process.
So, I know you talked about A-SCEND.

Can you tell us about how
A-SCEND automates that process?

- Yeah, so in and around
A-SCEND, there are some areas
where we're automating on the back end.
So, if you think about the evidence
that needs to be collected

in order to assert that
these controls are in place,

we allow our customers to
basically upload that evidence.
And then, we do things like deduplication.

So, it's this concept
of test funds use many

where you can actually look
at one piece of evidence
and maybe map it to multiple controls.

So, this is really to cut
down on the number of times

where you might request an
information security policy
or an AWS configuration setting.

So, that's one of the
pieces that we do that.
Another area where we're focused
is in around collection of the evidence.

So, since that information
now resides behind APIs,

which we can programmatically
hit and query,

we're able to actually go
and get access to those APIs
and pull back that information.

So, what we're really
focused in and around
are the biggest time-savers,

where did engineers used to
have to go and take screenshots

and do that for hours,
maybe even days to collect,

let's say, their access
control list from AWS.

So, can we actually just
go hit the same APIs,
pull back the security groups,
pull it into a document that can be used

both by the engineers and
the auditors to review,

and then associate it to
the control in order to say,

all right, this is how I'm gonna
perform my control testing.
So, within A-LIGN and A-SCEND,

those are the patterns
that we're working on
in getting them implemented.
- Wonderful.

And for SOC 2, do you do
any sampling for evidence?
Does that come into play as well?
- Sampling does come into play.

I think, we were talking about
this a little bit earlier

about scoping and making sure
that you have the proper scope
where we focus in and around scope
is really at the account level right now.
So, in AWS, we can have multiple accounts.

So, for your service, if
you're really just focused
on your production environment,
then we would focus on that account.
You may have multiple accounts
that actually support that service.
So, scoping comes into play,
making sure that we have that defined

for every assessment that
we would be focused on.
And we're doing that within A-SCEND.

And then, we'll continue to
improve upon our scoping ability
over time with the product.
- And we're talking about automation,

but I know, what parts of
auditing are still manual?
There's still some manual pieces to it,

so maybe you can let
us know what those are.
- Yeah, for the most part auditing,
there's quite a bit of human
in the loop automation going on right now,
and we're starting to improve upon that.
You're still finding yourself
manually uploading documentation.
I know we were talking about DuploCloud

and really in and around the
areas of AWS infrastructure
and what's there,
but there are other areas within SOC 2

that fall outside of the
infrastructure, quite a few.
- [Cheryl] Mm-hmm.
- So, things like organizational charts,

background checks, those things
might be a manual upload.
So, that does occur,

going through and actually
assessing and reviewing it.
There's a lot of work that's going on in

and around the concept of
configuration compliance,
or really looking at a setting
and then making a determination,

but there's still a
human component to that
to look at those reports,
make sure that over time
that that control is operating effectively
and then adding that to it as well.
So, there's still a considerable amount

of manual tasks that do occur,
- Mm-hmm.

- but we're moving towards
automation wherever possible.
- Yeah. That's great.
And since we're talking about,

we mentioned continuous compliance
or continuous monitoring,

how does DuploCloud provide
continuous monitoring?
- Yeah, I think, one of the core pieces
is that in fact, in our business model,

we almost don't charge them
'til they get to a point

where they have most of
the controls in place,

at least the initial
provisioning time controls.

The idea is that in today's
work with microservices

and so many different
AWS services and whatnot,
there is a constant change in the system.
So, it's important to have automation,
not just for constant provisioning,
but also to make sure that as people

are provisioning constantly,
they're not breaking anything.
So, DuploCloud does it in two ways.

One is that DuploCloud
is a provisioning tool,
so you actually use it to provision
and make changes on an ongoing basis.

So, that way, you're guaranteed
that it's not one time.

As you go forward, you would
continue to be compliant
because you continue to use that tool.
And then, of course there is, what we do
is that we tend to orchestrate independent
third party softwares,
which in this case is AWS Security Hub,
like AWS Config, ASEC and so on,
and provision them

and check whether the system
is in compliance or not.
So, that way, I think, we try to get,
not have our custom code to do monitoring,
so that way, we can keep ourselves on it.

So, do the provisioning,
orchestrate third party tools,

and then make sure things are
in alignment and compliance.

And if not, just make an alert
and then let people know.
- And SOC 2 is not a one and done,
it's an annual thing.
And one question I did forget to mention,

I ask earlier is what's the
normal reporting timeline
that you see?

- There's a beginning,
a middle, and an end
when we think about a SOC 2 project.

Typically the beginning,
planning stage, the ramp up.
So, depending on the client's readiness,

depending on if they've
done an audit in the past,

we'll gauge how much ramp
up time they're gonna need.

Typically, it's about six to
eight weeks on the front end

where we deliver that
information request list
is what we call it in the A-SCEND platform
that we were talking about earlier.

And the client will have an
opportunity to review that,

start drafting their responses,
start uploading evidence,

all the things that
we've been talking about.
And like I said, usually,

that's anywhere from six to
eight weeks of prep time.
Then, we'll get to the middle,
which is what we call the field work,

which is essentially when we
have our dedicated meetings
with the client,

we'll have our what we call
control walkthrough meetings,
where we'll essentially
go through each one of the SOC 2 criteria

and say, what are the controls
here that are applicable,
talk through that,

make sure that everything
is mapped appropriately.
And then, once we get through that stage
and get everything the way we need it
and get on the same page with the client,

then we go to the end
or the wrap up stage,
which is typically the part where we...
And there's a number of internal processes

that we have on our side
where it's QA review.

And we have a reporting team
that drafts up the report,

and there's a little bit of
back and forth internally.
Usually, that's about four to six weeks,

depending on, again, the
scope of the project,
how long the report is.

There's a number of factors
that play into that.
But typically, that last part
is about four to six weeks there.
- And then, for SOC 2 type two,
they have to have those controls in place

and running effectively.
- Right.

- So, what is that usually
that testing timeline,
is it three months?
Is it 12 months?
- Yeah. Great question.
So, again, it really depends.
Typically, the shortest assessment

that we'll do for a type
two is three months.

And then, we like to work
in quarterly intervals,

anywhere from three months,
six months, nine months,
we can accommodate

just depending on what
makes sense for the client.
And then, usually, what we like to do

is work our way up to that
12-month annual cycle,

and then going forward
on a continuous basis,
we'll come in once a year

and then basically just
review the controls

and the evidence that
has been accumulating
for the last 12 months or so.
- And with continuous compliance platforms
and things like that,

does that make that easier to
audit coming in the next year?

So, if you can see that
they've been compliant

with this control for
the past 12 months, is-

- Yes, yeah. It makes
a world of difference.
It really does because when I think back
when I first started,

we were still managing and
tracking a lot of things
through spreadsheets and it was manual,
and it was offline

and it was just very
messy and not efficient.
So, when I think about how far we've come,

even in just my short time
in the compliance world,
it's pretty amazing
because I don't know how we would operate

without the framework
(guest chuckles)
that we have now.
I can't imagine going back
to the way that we used to do things,
because it really does, it keeps

everything centralized
(Scott clears throat)
both for us as the auditors
and then of course our clients as well,
because our clients, obviously,
I think, they love working with us,
at least they tell us they do,

but of course-
- Keep get a distance.

- Yeah, of course
(Cheryl laughing)

they have their other
jobs and responsibilities
that they go back to throughout the year.

So, then, when we come back
next year for the audit,

it's always good for them
to have that refresher.

They can just pop back
into the A-SCEND portal.

- Yeah.
- Say, okay,
what did I provide last year?

Oh, that's what this was
and that sort of thing.
So, it's really helps on both sides
to keep everything centralized

together.
- Yeah. That's wonderful.

What are some of the common
risks and pitfalls you see

as someone starting out
their SOC 2 journey?

- So, I think that when we
talk about SOC 2 being painful,

I think that's synonymous
(chuckles) terms there.
So, what we try to like to do

is really help our clients
with the understanding piece.

And I can certainly let
these other gentlemen
here speak to some of the other...
When we talk,

go back to that people
process technology thing.
So, I think about,
a lot of our clients come to us
and they just don't know where to start.

They just don't understand
the SOC 2 criteria.
They don't understand the guidance.
They don't know what they're gonna need
to do to get everything in place.

So, at a line, a lot of
our marketing materials,

we have the mountain,
the mountain theme going.

So, we always like to say
that we're the Sherpas

helping our clients up
the mountain, so to speak.
So, I think, one of those things that,
again, from my under my perspective,
is just getting them familiar

with what we're gonna be doing
and letting them know that,
hey, we've done this before.
We've seen it a hundred times.

We're gonna get to the top
of the mountain, so to speak,
but we just gotta make sure

that we get all the
right controls in place.
- Yeah.
I think, what I've largely seen
is that a lot of organizations start off
and do a lot of infrastructure set up

without things in mind,
especially security.
So, what I would basically say
is that if you have a business

and you don't have to be
SOC 2 compliant on that day
or even requiring it.

But if you anticipate to
be in a regulated industry,
expect things like SOC 2 to be required.
So, make sure that when you do things,
try to do things right from the beginning,
because it's a lot harder technically
to actually go and patch things later.
And there are many examples.
If you have to change machines

out from one VPC to another
VPC, and things like that,

it's a lot harder change
things which are not encrypted.
It's not (chuckles) easy.
If you had to redo the whole thing

and whatnot, and that's
just the nature of things.
- Yeah, then,

they incur that cost.
- Let's keep that in mind.

There's more cost to that
when you have to re-engineer

and do all these things.
- Yeah. This is disruption.
And it's like so many things.
The time that you're save,

probably initially, you
probably lose all of it

at a much more critical time
of your journey in the company.

When someone is wanting
to go through SOC 2,
how soon should they enlist an auditor?

When should they contact
you during that process?

- I think, this goes back to
what we were just talking about
to prevent the rework
and this concept of backfilling security.
It's better to engage earlier

because we can help during
that discovery process

of really figuring out
what are your requirements.
From an independence perspective,
and Connor can talk about this as well,

on the implementation side,
we have to stay out of that.
So, we can give guidance.

We can give assistance
from that perspective,
but we can't be an implementer

of any of those controls
or the infrastructure.
It's good to get some additional guidance
as you're going through your audit prep,
as you're going through your readiness,
as you're going through your build-out,

and we're able to assist
from that perspective.
So, earlier is gonna be better.
- Yeah, absolutely.
The only thing I wanna add there, again,
just to not beat a dead horse,
but I think, coming to us

before you need the type
two SOC 2 report by tomorrow

is always, always,
(Venkat laughing)

a good thing.
- Yeah.

- So, really reaching out to
us before it's an emergency,
so that way, we have time
to evaluate what you've got going on.
And as I mentioned before,

the beginning, middle
and end of the cycle,
there's gonna be some ramp up time,
especially if you're new to it.
So, I think, just trying to get in contact

with us as early as
possible is gonna be great.
- And same with you, you were just saying,

- Yeah.
- maybe

a greenfield environment.
(Venkat chuckles)

Or one that they haven't-
- The sooner.

- Yes.
- Yeah. The sooner basically.
- And yeah, last question I have,

do you see that you're
doing a lot of migrations

- Right.
- to AWS?
Yes.
- Yeah, yeah.
So, the thing is that migrations,
in that sense, in the context of SOC 2
and compliance and our work is much easier

because migration is
almost always greenfield.
So, using the DuploCloud software,

they can focus on the app
migration versus dealing

with the compliance and
security of the infrastructure.
So, the idea is that use DuploCloud
to do all the provisioning and migration.

This is one thing less that
you have to worry about.
And like you said,

as far compliance is
concerned, within 95%.

And then just focus
- Mm-hmm.
- on the app, the migration, the downtime,
the data and stuff like that.
And that's where

the provisioning aspect
of the system comes in.
- So, Venkit,
are you seeing a lot of migrations to AWS

as they're starting
out their SOC 2 journey
or are they already built in the cloud?
- No, I think, it's both.
Obviously, a lot of the infrastructure
still exists outside of the public cloud.

So, it's both, but I
think, implementation-wise,

I would basically say,
if it's a migrations,
then SOC 2 and compliance

is something that they
have to worry about less
because when they're starting the journey
in the beginning with us
and these things are done out-of-box
using the DuploCloud software,

and they can purely focus on
their application and stuff.
But on the other hand,

if they're already operating
in the infrastructure,
that's fine too.
In fact, I would basically say 70%,
we deal with people who are already there
and 30% could be migrations.
And yeah, I think,

it all depends on how
much non-compliant work

has been done.
- Mm-hmm.

- And that's where the
challenges are to go and fix it.

- Oh, well, that's great.
Great information there.

And I wanna thank you
all for joining us today
and providing some great insight

and information about
SOC 2 compliance on AWS

and look forward
(upbeat music)
to doing some more things in the future.

- Yeah, absolutely.
- Yeah.

- Grateful here.
- Thank you.
